00:15:01.360 | that either had stutter or didn't have stutter.

00:15:15.940 | to things in the world.
00:15:17.140 | The old Hungarian psychologists I'm learning
00:15:19.300 | had this idea of two kinds of people.

00:15:23.820 | There are generators and projectors

00:15:42.100 | and break stuff and blow stuff up maybe,
00:15:44.180 | but also help things.
00:15:46.180 | And then there are these projectors
00:15:47.940 | that like to just kind of reflect on what they see.
00:15:52.220 | And they made the really important point, I think,
00:15:55.260 | that it's not that generators are good
00:15:57.340 | and projectors are bad.
00:15:58.180 | The world needs both,
00:15:59.500 | that they really work in a kind of symbiotic way.
00:16:02.220 | But your story captures the essence

00:20:55.700 | It's a place where if you have a certain rank
00:20:58.040 | on your shoulder, you will command respect
00:21:01.020 | and people have to listen to you.
00:21:03.100 | That's what it looks like.
00:21:04.380 | So it's an attractive place for people
00:21:08.140 | that have an authoritarian mindset,
00:21:10.820 | for people that want to just, hey,
00:21:12.720 | don't question what I'm saying,
00:21:15.040 | just shut up and do what I tell you to do.
00:21:16.340 | There's people that love that.
00:21:17.500 | There's people that want to live like that.
00:21:18.900 | You've worked for them, I've worked for them.

00:21:23.100 | throughout our lives.

00:21:28.600 | and have people listen to them.
00:21:29.680 | And so when they, when those people are 14 years old

00:21:55.000 | disciplined and orderly mindset can do well
00:21:59.060 | inside the military, especially in garrison.
00:22:02.500 | And I had to, again, we were talking about this earlier,
00:22:04.500 | the word garrison, I don't think there's a civilian
00:22:06.860 | equivalent to this word, but it basically means
00:22:09.580 | the non-combat situation.
00:22:11.200 | So when you're out on the parade field,
00:22:13.900 | when you're going through schooling,
00:22:18.300 | where there's no combat involved, when you're marching,
00:22:21.060 | like those kinds of things, we call that garrison.
00:22:24.260 | It's in the rear, it's not in combat.
00:22:26.540 | And the people with an authoritarian mindset
00:22:28.240 | actually do pretty well in garrison situations, why?
00:22:31.640 | Because things are orderly and you can predict
00:22:34.380 | what's going to happen and you do get a certain issue
00:22:36.620 | of gear and that gear is gonna be delivered on time
00:22:40.100 | and you're gonna shoot this number of rounds
00:22:41.880 | down at the range and everything is going to go
00:22:44.220 | according to plan, that's what garrison is.
00:22:46.540 | And so those people join the military,
00:22:50.200 | they're attracted to that and they end up doing well
00:22:53.120 | in peace time.
00:22:54.080 | Now, unfortunately for them, combat is a lot different.
00:22:59.560 | Nothing goes the way it's supposed to go.
00:23:01.860 | The bullets don't get delivered on time.
00:23:04.160 | The enemy has a vote on the way things are going to unfold
00:23:07.020 | and you end up in combat in being
00:23:08.680 | in very chaotic situations.
00:23:10.420 | So the type of person that thrives in combat
00:23:14.320 | has a more open mind, has a more flexible mind,
00:23:18.820 | is paying more attention to the input
00:23:22.260 | that they're receiving.
00:23:23.660 | As opposed to someone with authoritarian mindset,
00:23:25.380 | they don't listen to anybody else.

00:47:24.360 | and this isn't a push for intermittent fasting

00:50:44.200 | that we forget that we're doing, like walking.
00:50:46.560 | And then we have neural circuits

00:50:53.440 | and in the background, just kind of hum in the background
00:50:55.480 | and take care of all the stuff like heartbeat breathing

01:02:56.780 | They don't know how to recover from a loss

01:03:02.040 | and once you get to a SEAL team,
01:03:04.260 | you've got people that are generally speaking
01:03:08.320 | gonna be pretty resilient
01:03:09.560 | when it comes to dealing with a loss.
01:03:12.980 | Not only that, I mean, you just get used to,
01:03:14.660 | you talk about losing people.
01:03:16.400 | You're friends with this guy.
01:03:17.800 | You meet this guy in SEAL training.
01:03:19.360 | Hey, this guy seems like a stud.
01:03:20.940 | Oh, he's just gonna quit.
01:03:22.340 | And you're gonna lose five, six, seven people, eight people.
01:03:26.140 | People quit so fast, you don't even keep track of them.
01:03:28.920 | So you're just gonna lose.
01:03:29.840 | You're just gonna get used to it.
01:03:32.240 | So there's that.
01:03:33.240 | Now, once you're in the teams
01:03:35.760 | and what you're talking about is now you start taking
01:03:38.000 | much more significant loss.
01:03:39.680 | You're not losing a race, you're losing one of your friends.
01:03:41.460 | And this is what, from a leadership perspective,
01:03:43.940 | you have to pay attention to.

01:03:48.780 | you're basically in charge of a mob.

01:35:19.700 | of one domain of life and they end up very, very isolated.
01:35:23.260 | So I'd love for you to kind of share with us
01:35:24.900 | what your recollections are kind of like
01:35:26.260 | the first time you realized kind of like,
01:35:28.840 | yeah, like I'm good in a bunch of different places.
01:35:31.620 | I'm safe or I'm whatever.
01:35:33.740 | 'Cause I think this also relates to confidence.
01:35:38.480 | - You know, I'm glad you are giving me
01:35:41.380 | the benefit of the doubt on going in the teams
01:35:43.940 | and being like, oh, hey man, it looks like guys are drinking
01:35:47.300 | and I haven't really drank before.
01:35:48.560 | And it seems like these guys are having a good time.
01:35:51.220 | Let's go have a good time with these guys.
01:35:52.420 | And that's kind of what I did, right?
01:35:54.260 | As far as, and you know, I look at it now
01:36:00.060 | and unfortunately for me, you know,
01:36:02.940 | I look at alcohol now as just,
01:36:04.820 | I've seen it destroy so many people
01:36:08.060 | that I've now kind of look at it and go,
01:36:11.420 | man, I don't think people should drink.
01:36:14.620 | And look, I get it.
01:36:15.720 | I'm kind of an example.
01:36:16.760 | Like I used to drink and go out and have a good time
01:36:19.400 | and it wasn't that big of a deal.
01:36:20.240 | It didn't negatively impact me in some dramatic way.
01:36:23.160 | But I have so many friends that it is horrible for.
01:36:28.160 | It is all but ruined their lives.
01:36:31.860 | And you know, it's totally legal, which is kind of bizarre.
01:36:36.780 | So I think that figuring that out when I look back
01:36:40.940 | and the culture in the SEAL teams was very,
01:36:43.920 | there was very alcohol centric.
01:36:47.780 | And part of that is because, you know,
01:36:49.220 | that you got like, it's just like a fraternity
01:36:51.820 | is alcohol centric or a football team is out.
01:36:55.680 | 'Cause you've got a bunch of young dudes
01:36:56.800 | that are gonna drink and have a good time.
01:36:58.340 | So it just sort of a young dude kind of thing.
01:37:02.540 | And unfortunately it ends up ruining a lot of people's lives
01:37:07.460 | and they make bad decisions and they do stupid things
01:37:10.060 | and it's just not good.
01:37:11.860 | And I think the culture is moving away from that
01:37:14.620 | a little bit in the SEAL teams.
01:37:16.180 | You know, my alcohol brief used to say,
01:37:21.820 | you know, I used to tell my guys, if you go out,
01:37:25.220 | you get a DUI, you get put in jail for a fight,
01:37:29.180 | you get hurt because you're doing something drunk,
01:37:32.580 | you just did Al-Qaeda's job for them.
01:37:35.400 | You just did Al-Qaeda's,
01:37:36.340 | they wanna take you off the battlefield
01:37:37.780 | and you just took yourself off the battlefield.
01:37:39.140 | You can't go on deployment now.
01:37:40.340 | And that would always hit guys.
01:37:43.220 | And I think that that's, you know,
01:37:45.380 | the SEAL teams kind of leaning in that direction more,
01:37:47.840 | realizing the negativity of alcohol.
01:37:51.460 | I wish I would have realized that earlier.
01:37:54.500 | I wish I would have been a better leader
01:37:56.020 | and recognize that at an earlier stage
01:37:57.940 | and recognize that just because I was kind of getting away
01:38:00.300 | with it, meaning it didn't really,
01:38:03.980 | I didn't wake up in the morning going,
01:38:05.460 | man, I can't wait to get drunk.
01:38:06.300 | I never really had that feeling.

01:38:12.580 | and you know, there's people that can operate
01:38:16.220 | and be functional and it doesn't really impact their lives,
01:38:18.700 | but there's a lot of people that don't.
01:38:19.980 | And I don't think it's worth the dice roll
01:38:21.940 | to start drinking.
01:38:23.480 | I just don't think it's worth the dice roll.
01:38:24.780 | What do you get out of it?
01:38:26.260 | So I think that overall, that's why,
01:38:30.060 | if when I think about alcohol,

01:38:35.340 | and I don't like it.

01:38:40.940 | and we shouldn't do this.
01:38:42.340 | And unfortunately I didn't.

01:38:46.420 | And it did bring me back to my roots
01:38:49.040 | because when I was a kid, it was like, alcohol is weak.
01:38:52.260 | And you look at these guys,

01:53:21.040 | that's what it is, man.
01:53:26.400 | I won't fail those guys.
01:53:29.920 | - Thanks for sharing that.
01:53:32.920 | Yeah, I think anyone listening to this
01:53:39.800 | feels what I feel right now, which is
01:53:43.600 | it's very clear that the depth of emotion
01:53:48.280 | for people that we care about and lose

02:43:37.360 | And you know, the rest of the team
02:43:40.940 | probably need to pull you aside and say, hey man,
02:43:42.680 | like I know you really care about that and that's awesome,
02:43:45.300 | but everyone really wants to hear about this other stuff.
02:43:49.700 | So let's tie it in together.
02:43:51.420 | Let's expand this specific thing you want to talk about.
02:43:54.640 | So being able to take a step back, detach,
02:43:56.940 | and see the bigger picture,
02:43:58.340 | to me is the true superpower of life, of life.
02:44:03.340 | And it's a lot harder than it sounds.
02:44:06.700 | And you know, this goes back to when you start talking
02:44:10.060 | about people that are having,
02:44:12.660 | going through struggles in life, right?
02:44:14.860 | And I've described this before as, you know,
02:44:17.540 | if I'm looking at you and you're in a bad state, right?
02:44:22.040 | You're depressed, you're sad, you're moping around,
02:44:25.120 | you're not getting anything done.
02:44:26.820 | And I'm looking at you from the outside
02:44:30.300 | and I'm thinking for me,

02:44:34.040 | I see the storm cloud around your head and you're in there.
02:44:38.660 | And all you see, no matter what direction you look is storm.
02:44:43.100 | All you see is darkness.
02:44:44.980 | I'm outside and I'm looking and I'm like,

02:44:48.660 | He's got a good team around him.
02:44:50.420 | Like he's got all these things going for him."
02:44:52.020 | But you in that state, you literally cannot see anything
02:44:57.020 | but the darkness of the storm.
02:45:00.100 | And that's what's so scary about when people enter that mode
02:45:04.940 | is you can look, I can look at it from the outside
02:45:07.560 | and be like, "Andrew, you just got to move like four feet
02:45:10.480 | forward and you're going to be through this thing."

02:45:18.440 | So helping people move forward, take action
02:45:21.900 | and be able to get that perspective, detach
02:45:24.660 | and get outside themselves, get outside their own heads.
02:45:28.400 | Tim Ferriss said, "Get out of your head, get into your body.
02:45:30.400 | That's one way to do it, take action, go do things."
02:45:33.540 | But it's very scary and I'm sure you've had this experience
02:45:37.220 | where you're talking to someone that you know
02:45:40.140 | and they're bogged down in whatever problem it is,
02:45:43.600 | whatever stress they're under and you're looking at them
02:45:47.240 | going, "Hey man, it's going to be okay."

02:46:27.000 | towards me and you're going to get out of this storm."

02:46:36.060 | and trying to give people that super power of detachment

02:56:39.940 | And I wrote about leadership strategy and tactics
02:56:41.620 | where I recognized like in a moment
02:56:46.220 | what detachment was and how helpful it was.
02:56:48.820 | I'm on an oil rig doing a training mission.
02:56:53.380 | My whole platoon is in a skirmish line
02:56:56.340 | looking at a large area of the oil rig

02:57:05.360 | And I'm standing in this skirmish line.
02:57:07.840 | And by the way, I'm the youngest
02:57:09.080 | and most junior guy in my platoon.
02:57:10.420 | And I'm standing there looking down the site of my weapon
02:57:14.000 | and I'm waiting for someone to make a call
02:57:15.640 | and tell us what to do.
02:57:16.740 | And I wait for five seconds and I wait for 10 seconds
02:57:20.260 | and I wait for 20 seconds and no one's saying anything.
02:57:22.840 | And we're waiting for a leader in my platoon
02:57:25.920 | to make a call to tell us what to do, tell me what to do.
02:57:30.020 | And finally after like 30 seconds,
02:57:31.860 | which seems like an eternity, I can't take it anymore.
02:57:35.620 | And so I take a step like a foot, one foot step, 12 inches,
02:57:40.620 | I take a step off the skirmish line.
02:57:43.580 | I look to my left, I look to my right
02:57:45.300 | and what I see is every other guy in my platoon
02:57:48.080 | is staring down their weapon.
02:57:49.660 | Staring down the site of their weapon
02:57:51.540 | which means their field of view is tiny.
02:57:54.920 | It's like a 20 degree field of view.
02:57:56.660 | You're looking down the scope of your weapon
02:57:58.660 | or the site of your weapon
02:58:00.140 | and that's how big their field of view is.
02:58:01.500 | I'm looking, I'm thinking, oh, there's my platoon commander,
02:58:04.500 | he's looking down the scope, the site of his weapon.
02:58:06.800 | There's my platoon chief,
02:58:07.640 | he's looking down the side of his weapon.
02:58:08.660 | There's my leading petty officer,
02:58:09.660 | he's looking down the side of his weapon.
02:58:10.940 | There's my assistant platoon commander,
02:58:11.980 | he's looking down the, so everyone in the platoon
02:58:14.020 | is looking down the side of their weapon
02:58:15.340 | which means they all have a very narrow field of vision.
02:58:20.340 | Well, when I take a step back and look to my left
02:58:23.460 | and look to my right,
02:58:24.300 | guess what kind of field of vision I got?
02:58:25.540 | I got a massive one.
02:58:26.720 | I can see the whole scene and I can see exactly
02:58:29.480 | what it is we need to do.
02:58:31.720 | And at that moment, look, as a new guy,
02:58:34.300 | you need to keep your mouth shut.
02:58:35.560 | You don't say anything.
02:58:37.400 | And I'm thinking, well, but no one else is saying anything.
02:58:40.540 | So I muster up all the courage I can
02:58:43.640 | and I open my mouth and I say, hold left, clear right,
02:58:47.560 | which is a basic tactical call.
02:58:50.400 | Nope, nope, nope.
02:58:51.800 | This is not a patent level genius maneuver.
02:58:54.360 | It's just a normal call to make in a situation
02:58:56.200 | that we were in.
02:58:57.040 | I say, hold left, clear right.
02:58:58.360 | And I'm expecting to get kind of slapped,
02:59:00.880 | told, shut up, new guy.
02:59:02.480 | But instead, everyone just repeats the call,
02:59:04.180 | hold left, clear right, hold left, clear right.
02:59:05.960 | And we execute the maneuver and we finish the clearance
02:59:08.660 | of this oil rig and we get done.
02:59:11.120 | We get to the top of the oil rig,
02:59:12.900 | which means we cleared the whole thing.
02:59:13.840 | We're on the helo deck at the top and we go into a debrief.
02:59:17.060 | And now I'm expecting, okay, now I'm gonna get told,
02:59:19.120 | hey, what were you doing?
02:59:20.280 | You need to keep your mouth shut.
02:59:22.360 | And instead, the platoon chief goes,
02:59:23.680 | hey, Johnco, good call on the cellar deck down there.
02:59:27.760 | And I was kind of like, yeah, that's right.
02:59:30.880 | But then I thought to myself, hold on a second.
02:59:32.780 | Why, if I'm the youngest, most junior guy in this platoon,
02:59:36.740 | why was I able to see what we needed to do
02:59:39.280 | and make that call?
02:59:40.120 | Why did that just happen?
02:59:41.440 | And then I realized it was 'cause I took a step back,
02:59:45.400 | to use your term, I broadened my field of view,
02:59:50.360 | which allowed me to think more clearly,
02:59:52.760 | 'cause instead of being hyper-focused and narrowly focused,
02:59:55.180 | I broadened my range of vision.
02:59:57.240 | I took a breath before I made my call, right?
03:00:00.060 | I had to take a nice breath to speak clearly.
03:00:04.720 | And I realized that taking a step back and detaching,
03:00:09.100 | I got to see infinitely more
03:00:11.560 | than even the most experienced guys in my platoon.
03:00:14.820 | And I started doing it all the time.
03:00:16.920 | And I started doing it in land warfare.
03:00:18.900 | I started doing it in urban combat.
03:00:20.540 | I started doing it in all these tactical training scenarios.
03:00:23.640 | These are just training, this is the 90s.
03:00:25.000 | Started doing these training scenarios,
03:00:26.140 | and it always allowed me to see what we needed to do.
03:00:31.140 | And then I started doing it
03:00:35.020 | like when I was having conversations with people
03:00:37.000 | and having a conversation with my platoon chief,
03:00:38.580 | and I can see that he's starting
03:00:39.700 | to turn a little red in the face,
03:00:40.860 | and we're about to argue about something.
03:00:43.180 | I said, oh, wait a second.
03:00:44.140 | I'm taking a step back, look and go,
03:00:45.220 | he's getting mad right now, and he's the platoon chief.
03:00:48.300 | You better just deescalate this thing real quick.
03:00:51.580 | And I'd say, hey, you know what, chief, that sounds good.
03:00:53.200 | Let me go take a, let me go relook at the plan or whatever.
03:00:56.940 | And so I started to do this kinda with my normal life,
03:01:01.860 | was to not get wrapped up in my own emotions,
03:01:04.460 | not get wrapped up in the gunfight
03:01:06.980 | that was happening right in front of my face,
03:01:09.060 | not to get wrapped up in the details of what was going on,
03:01:12.580 | but instead take a step back, detach, look around,
03:01:17.680 | and then you can make a much, much better decision.
03:01:20.920 | And it's not, it's exponential.
03:01:24.660 | If you're looking down the sights of your weapon
03:01:28.220 | and you take a step back and you look around,
03:01:31.040 | it's exponential how much more you can see.
03:01:33.480 | Now, listen, if you are the only person in a gunfight,
03:01:36.000 | it's gonna be harder for you to do that
03:01:37.240 | 'cause you gotta be focused on whatever you're shooting at.
03:01:39.580 | But when you have 16 guys or 20 guys,
03:01:41.840 | they're all looking in the same direction,
03:01:43.340 | it's very easy to be the guy that goes,
03:01:44.960 | I'm gonna take a step back, look around, make a call.
03:01:48.980 | So when you talk about the mechanics,
03:01:52.020 | when I teach this to people now, the mechanics of it,
03:01:56.480 | take a step back.
03:01:57.900 | Literally, you and I are at a meeting,
03:02:00.240 | there's a bunch of people,
03:02:01.080 | this starts to get heated argument,
03:02:02.680 | I will literally push my chair back away from the table,
03:02:06.080 | change my perspective, open, widen my field of view.
03:02:12.740 | The other thing, like in the SEAL teams,
03:02:15.140 | you don't wanna sound panicked on the radio
03:02:18.480 | for a couple reasons.
03:02:21.040 | Number one, because when you panic on the radio,
03:02:22.820 | it's gonna cause other people to panic.
03:02:23.900 | Number two, if you panic on the radio
03:02:25.680 | and you sound panicked, everyone's gonna make fun of you.
03:02:27.280 | So when you get back from the mission,
03:02:29.020 | everything's gonna go, you sounded like a baby out there.
03:02:32.080 | So what would I do before I would key up my radio?
03:02:35.340 | Take a breath.
03:02:38.000 | And so here I'm manually slowing down my breath,
03:02:41.800 | I'm broadening my field of view.
03:02:43.400 | So if you're in a meeting or you're at the supermarket
03:02:48.400 | parking lot and someone starts to yell at you,
03:02:52.140 | take a step back, take a breath, broaden your field of view,
03:02:55.960 | detach from those emotions that you're having
03:02:58.500 | and make some space.
03:03:01.060 | And that's how I go through the mechanics of detachment.
03:03:04.840 | Now I can tell you right now,
03:03:07.000 | I mean, when you do this all the time,
03:03:09.440 | which I kind of do this all the time,
03:03:12.160 | I don't really have to like step back,
03:03:14.040 | but when you're starting to be able to try and do this,
03:03:16.080 | absolutely, make them, and I'll tell you,
03:03:18.200 | here's another like weird little nuance thing.
03:03:20.560 | Lift your chin up and put your hands down.
03:03:26.640 | Now this isn't, not in a combat situation,
03:03:28.600 | not in a fight, but here's the thing.
03:03:30.440 | When I get defensive, what am I gonna do?
03:03:34.640 | I'm gonna raise my hands up and put my chin down.
03:03:36.080 | That's like a fighting mode.
03:03:37.320 | So if you and I are having a discussion
03:03:39.000 | and I'm starting to get heated and I'm starting to like,
03:03:41.040 | oh, he's not listening to me,
03:03:42.800 | instead of me putting my chin down and putting my hands
03:03:46.720 | like up to where I can put them in your face a little bit,
03:03:49.480 | no, I'm actually gonna take a step back.
03:03:50.920 | I'm gonna say, put my chin up.
03:03:53.200 | It changes my perspective a little bit more,
03:03:54.880 | changes my visual perspective,
03:03:56.560 | just changing the angle of my head.
03:03:58.720 | Take a step back, put my hands down.
03:04:00.600 | I'm not being in a defensive mood.
03:04:01.600 | I actually wanna hear what you have to say.
03:04:04.440 | And if I start listening to what you have to say
03:04:06.960 | and not talking, it's very hard to be detached
03:04:09.440 | when you're talking.
03:04:10.600 | It's another key component.
03:04:12.080 | You wanna detach, shut your mouth.
03:04:14.600 | So I'm in meetings, you know,
03:04:16.560 | in a bunch of different companies.
03:04:18.520 | I'm running, I have a bunch of,
03:04:19.800 | I own a bunch of different companies.
03:04:21.220 | I'm in a meeting in my companies.
03:04:23.040 | I'm not the one that's doing all the talking.
03:04:24.600 | In fact, I'm doing mostly listening.
03:04:26.500 | When I'm in task unit bruiser, my task unit,
03:04:29.520 | I'm not sitting there giving the entire brief.
03:04:32.160 | No, I'm letting the platoon chief and the platoon
03:04:34.000 | commanders give those briefs.
03:04:36.840 | And that way I'm detached.
03:04:37.960 | I'm listening to what they have to say.
03:04:39.920 | I'm more capable of seeing what holes there are
03:04:44.280 | in their plans by not moving my mouth,
03:04:47.600 | not talking, I'm listening.
03:04:50.180 | So those are some of the methodologies that I use
03:04:52.800 | and that I advise people to use
03:04:54.320 | in order to effectively start down the pathway
03:04:59.000 | of being able to detach in various scenarios.
03:05:01.600 | - I love it.
03:05:04.720 | Again, I'm saying I love it because I do love it.
03:05:06.800 | And thank you.
03:05:07.640 | I think it's a wonderful technique.
03:05:09.000 | We've talked before on your podcast
03:05:10.620 | and some of my listeners, maybe not all to this podcast,
03:05:13.920 | will be familiar with the fact that when we narrowly focus
03:05:16.600 | our gaze on one target, a number of things happen.
03:05:19.400 | Our visual world becomes constricted, of course,
03:05:22.000 | but also that we start slicing time more finely
03:05:24.760 | and the dopamine system tends to start doing a kind
03:05:27.640 | of anticipation and trying to guide and direct things
03:05:30.640 | in that narrow tunnel of view.
03:05:32.400 | Whereas when we literally take on panoramic visions
03:05:35.360 | and not necessarily moving our head around,
03:05:36.620 | although one could, but broadening our field of view
03:05:38.600 | or looking at a horizon, especially if we're walking,
03:05:41.300 | but getting that kind of,
03:05:42.520 | not kind of getting a broader field of view,
03:05:44.880 | we slice time differently.
03:05:47.280 | Things don't feel as imposing on us.
03:05:50.340 | This is the physiological substrate
03:05:52.440 | underlying what you're describing.
03:05:54.000 | And I think it goes a step further
03:05:56.800 | because in that open, larger aperture
03:06:00.980 | of visual understanding, there's an open larger window
03:06:04.200 | of cognitive understanding and new options start to surface.
03:06:08.120 | Right, I mean, I think this is,
03:06:09.580 | I've long been fascinated by the fact that this actually,
03:06:12.140 | I'll tell this real quick story.
03:06:13.780 | In 2015, I was, I went over to Spain
03:06:17.740 | to do some mountaineering with Wim Hof.
03:06:20.060 | Okay, this wasn't because I wanted a podcast.

03:06:31.900 | Almost ripped my left leg off in a stunt

03:06:37.800 | that I never should have done.

03:06:43.020 | on the ground next to like a curb
03:06:44.860 | in this parking lot before a hike.

03:06:50.420 | And he's like, "Look."

03:07:19.920 | at all scales all the time.

03:08:54.800 | really makes us myopic, really makes us nearsighted.

03:09:02.300 | We do events with companies, businesses,
03:09:05.700 | and we go offsite somewhere where they're detached.
03:09:10.700 | They're just, they're de facto detached
03:09:14.080 | from their day-to-day business.
03:09:16.680 | You pull someone out of their business for two days
03:09:18.200 | and all of a sudden they start seeing the solutions.
03:09:20.960 | They never see them.
03:09:22.600 | It's a lot harder for them to see them
03:09:24.200 | when they're in the firefight.
03:09:26.200 | You get them out of the firefight.
03:09:27.360 | It's hard for them to see it
03:09:28.460 | when they're in that acquisition that they're doing.
03:09:31.400 | How are we gonna merge these two cultures?
03:09:33.000 | This is gonna be impossible.
03:09:34.280 | Boom, pull them out.
03:09:35.560 | All right, let's talk about the two cultures.
03:09:37.480 | And let's talk about what possible outcomes there are.
03:09:40.000 | And all of a sudden when you get them to take a step back,
03:09:42.740 | the solutions will appear.
03:09:45.400 | And it is true in a gunfight.
03:09:47.000 | Now listen, if it's a one-on-one gunfight,
03:09:49.360 | even then the ability to take a step back
03:09:53.080 | and look around or use your peripheral vision,
03:09:56.320 | you have to be able to do this.
03:09:58.000 | It's gonna increase, it's exponential how much it,
03:10:01.480 | that's why it's like a superpower.
03:10:02.880 | It's like cheating.
03:10:04.040 | It's like cheating.
03:10:05.520 | You know, I was speaking of Seth Stone.
03:10:08.080 | Seth Stone took over, he became a task unit commander,
03:10:12.560 | a troop commander when we got back from Ramadi.

03:10:54.760 | or full mission profile.

03:11:38.460 | another guy gets killed with laser.

03:11:43.760 | And I was like, no, let him figure it out.

03:11:49.980 | just laser dead, but they're dead.
03:11:52.520 | And he hits me again and he's like, bro, let me tell him.
03:11:55.200 | And I go, all right, go ahead and tell him.
03:11:57.460 | And so he just crouches down next to one of the guys
03:11:59.640 | and bangs him on the shoulder, go, peel right.
03:12:02.460 | And which is, again, it's just a fundamental basic call.
03:12:06.840 | And the guy shouts it out, peel right,
03:12:08.520 | and they start peeling right.

03:12:10.520 | they're all out of the kill zone and everything's okay.
03:12:13.640 | And then Seth looks at me and he goes,
03:12:16.120 | man, this is so easy way up here.

03:12:48.040 | I was constantly just looking around.
03:12:50.400 | So that's why it seems like a magic power, right?
03:12:53.360 | It's like a superpower 'cause Seth's down there
03:12:56.440 | with his gun and he's shooting.

03:13:00.760 | go to that ridge line right there, set security, boom.
03:13:02.480 | And how did Jaco see that?
03:13:05.320 | Jaco must be a tactical genius.
03:13:06.640 | No, I'm not a tactical genius.
03:13:08.320 | I'm just taking a step back and looking around.
03:13:10.880 | And like you just said, it applies to everything
03:13:13.520 | that we do if you're having a conversation
03:13:16.240 | with your significant other and you
03:13:18.120 | start to see that they're getting
03:13:20.620 | frustrated about something.
03:13:22.180 | Now look, if you're in the conversation 100%,
03:13:26.220 | you're going to get frustrated too.
03:13:27.640 | You're going to get frustrated, they're frustrated.
03:13:29.200 | Next thing you know, you've got an emotional argument going on.
03:13:33.040 | Whereas if you can take a mental step back and say, wait a minute,
03:13:35.920 | why are they frustrated right now?
03:13:38.320 | Oh, because I'm trying to solve their problem
03:13:41.100 | when really what they're looking to do is vent.
03:13:43.020 | OK, got it.
03:13:44.200 | Let them vent.
03:13:44.800 | OK, cool.
03:13:45.480 | Oh, that sounds horrible.
03:13:47.080 | What do you think you're going to do?
03:13:48.640 | Instead of saying, well, if that's the problem,
03:13:49.880 | here's what you should do.
03:13:50.500 | Because people are always looking for that.
03:13:52.760 | So yeah, this thing, this ability is--
03:13:55.040 | and it's something that can absolutely be trained.
03:13:57.640 | And that's what's cool about it, can absolutely be trained.
03:14:00.840 | It's not a natural gift.
03:14:03.240 | Some people will be better at it than others.
03:14:05.520 | But it's something that you can train.
03:14:07.280 | And I used to see guys develop it.
03:14:08.760 | And I see people develop it now in the business world
03:14:10.920 | where they'll report back to me.
03:14:13.840 | You know, oh, we had a meeting with the union today.
03:14:15.960 | And the union started escalating what they wanted to do.
03:14:19.000 | And I just detached.
03:14:21.080 | And we ended up de-escalating.
03:14:22.640 | And now we've got a solution.
03:14:23.840 | So this is an absolute skill set that can be learned.
03:14:27.360 | And that's what makes it especially nice.
03:14:31.680 | Because there's some people-- look, if you're very articulate,
03:14:36.520 | born very-- some people are born more articulate
03:14:39.040 | than other people.
03:14:40.040 | Some people are born with an ability
03:14:43.280 | to simplify things more than others.
03:14:45.240 | And you can train.
03:14:46.040 | You can become more articulate.
03:14:47.440 | You can learn to simplify things more.
03:14:51.100 | And some people are going to be naturally good at detaching.
03:14:53.800 | But everyone can get better at it.
03:14:56.040 | And that's a beautiful thing.
03:14:57.800 | It is a beautiful thing.
03:14:58.780 | And I'm highly incentivized to do this.
03:15:00.520 | I mean, there are areas of my life
03:15:01.940 | that are going really well that I also want to apply it there.
03:15:05.040 | I think that I've tended to rely on people close to me as a way
03:15:08.560 | to access this detachment.
03:15:11.520 | I will be very direct in saying that I am not
03:15:14.740 | the leader of my podcast.
03:15:16.280 | There is a leader.
03:15:17.340 | It is not me.
03:15:18.920 | I'm part of the team.
03:15:20.320 | But it is not me.
03:15:21.500 | And I often rely on his input.
03:15:25.240 | And sometimes that input is solicited.
03:15:27.260 | And sometimes it's not.
03:15:28.960 | One place, for instance, where you see people getting really
03:15:31.880 | myopic is on social media.
03:15:34.720 | And I've experienced this.
03:15:38.640 | I'd love to say that I'm always non-reactive.
03:15:41.080 | And I think, in general, I take the stance that I have filters.
03:15:45.160 | So I have filters.
03:15:47.480 | I know why I'm there.
03:15:48.960 | I'm interested in being a teacher and a giver
03:15:50.800 | and informing people about the beauty and utility of biology.
03:15:54.420 | That's why I say it's not a mission statement.
03:15:56.160 | It's a fact.
03:15:57.220 | That's what I care about.
03:15:58.680 | Anything that doesn't fit through that filter,
03:16:01.060 | I don't really have any business doing.
03:16:02.640 | But occasionally, I like to make a joke or something.
03:16:04.800 | But occasionally, something comes through.
03:16:06.800 | And I find myself, wait a second.
03:16:08.680 | And you get sucked into that tunnel.
03:16:11.480 | And sometimes it's observing other people in tunnels.
03:16:14.180 | And when you're not in the tunnel,
03:16:15.600 | it's so obvious what's happening.
03:16:17.840 | You're watching, in some cases, people just
03:16:19.760 | dragging their lives, in some cases,
03:16:21.300 | sinking their entire careers.
03:16:22.500 | I mean, the former chair of psychiatry
03:16:24.480 | at Columbia University in New York
03:16:26.640 | made an absolutely foolish, truly insensitive, totally
03:16:32.080 | inappropriate tweet.
03:16:33.880 | That's my opinion.
03:16:34.880 | And I think it was the opinion of all the people that
03:16:37.000 | fired him from his job.
03:16:38.020 | This person who was at the apex of his career
03:16:40.680 | lost his job for saying something terrible.
03:16:44.560 | And in retrospect, was like, said something like,
03:16:46.920 | I don't know what I was thinking, you know?
03:16:49.060 | And so this guy's a psychiatrist.
